===Alternative forms===
In complex characters, often written with last two strokes different, as in [[疋]]; compare [[昰]] and [[是]].

===Han character===
{{Han char|rn=77|rad=止|as=01|sn=5|four=10101|canj=MYLM|ids=⿱一止}}

====Usage notes====
* {{sense|tally marks|5}} The successive strokes of {{m|mul|sc=Hani|正}} ([[Image:Tally marks 3.svg|100px|East Asian tally marks 1 through 5]]) are used in China, Japan, and Korea to designate tallies in votes, scores, points, sushi orders, and the like, much as [[Image:Tally b05.svg]] is used in Europe, Africa, Australia, and North America. Tallies beyond five are written with a {{m|mul|sc=Hani|正}} for each group of five, followed by the remainder. For example, a tally of twelve [[Image:Tally b12.svg|12 in tally marks as used in Europe, Zimbabwe, Australia, and North America]] is written as {{lang|und|sc=Hani|正正丅}}.

===Glyph origin===
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|丁|止|ls=psc|c1=p|c2=s|t2=foot}} – to go on a long journey. Original form of {{och-l|征|to go on long campaign}}.

===Etymology===
Sino-Tibetan or area word: “centre; target; first (month); straight; correct”.

Compare {{cog|lus|dîng||to go straight or direct (as person, arrow etc.); to go straight through without breaking the journey; straight; direct}}. {{zh-ref|Matisoff}} sets up {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*m-tyak/ŋ ~ tik/ŋ||good; very; real; straight}} for this, which includes {{lang|zh|正}}, {{och-l|直|straight; right}} and {{och-l|實|solid; true}}.

Additionally, {{zh-ref|Matisoff}} has {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*t(r)waŋ||straight; straighten}}, whence {{cog|cdm||dʰeŋ-|straight}}, {{cog|kac|ding||straight}}, {{cog|bo|དྲང་པོ||straight; correct; upright; just; fair}}, {{cog|my|တန်း||straight; to head straight for}}. Also compare {{cog|km|ទៀង||accurate; correct; exact; precise; honest}}.

Derivatives:
* {{och-l|征|to go straight > to go on a journey}}
* {{och-l|政|correct; to govern; government; to determine}}
* {{och-l|整|orderly; to arrange; to dispose}}

===Number===
'''正''' ([[せい]], [[sei]])

# A number of 10<sup>40</sup> in modern Japanese since 17th century.
# 5. Similar to four vertical lines followed by a slanted horizontal line crossing through them, this character is used to count to 5 stroke by stroke. Thus this kanji written up to the third stroke represents 3. After the fifth and final stroke, when this character is completed, one starts writing this character again to count to higher numbers.

[[Category:Japanese numeral symbols|10^40]]
